children.value: By default, Hummingbot uses the order book you're trading in to generate the
(between the top bid and the top ask) as a starting price to calculate maker order prices.
With this feature, users have the option to choose a different price reference for your orders such as
. Users can also use a different order book such as an external
In a situation where the calculation of maker order prices from external sources would result in the order matching any existing orders on the order book, such order will be ignored unless

exchange: binance
                 market: BTC-USDC
             bid_spread: 1
             ask_spread: 1

price_source: current_market
             price_type: mid_price
  price_source_exchange: None
    price_source_market: None
        take_if_crossed: None
price_source_custom_api: None
Users can also use an external market from another exchange supported by Hummingbot as the price reference when creating orders.
In the example below, we're trading on BTC-USDC pair in Binance while using the mid price of BTC-USDT market from Crypto.com exchange.

exchange: binance
                 market: BTC-USDC
             bid_spread: 1
             ask_spread: 1

price_source: external_market
             price_type: mid_price
  price_source_exchange: crypto_com
    price_source_market: BTC-USDT
        take_if_crossed: True
price_source_custom_api: None
command to change the price reference to
is optional as this only allows users to take existing orders from the order book if there is an existing match.

<Callout
  type="note"
  body="Currently, the external price source cannot be the same as the maker exchange (i.e. if the bot is trading on Binance, the `price_source_exchange` cannot be Binance)."
/>
Custom API is mostly used by advanced users or developers for using a different price reference. Take note that
with the API URL indicated in

price_source: custom_api
             price_type: mid_price
  price_source_exchange: None
    price_source_market: None
        take_if_crossed: None
price_source_custom_api: https://www.your-custom-api-url.com/
The API GET request should return a decimal number corresponding to a market price for the asset pair you are trading on.
When to use an external price source
External price source is valuable when your bot is market making for a relatively illiquid trading pair, but a more liquid pair with the same underlying exposure is available on a different exchange.
Suppose we are market making for the
trading pair. The exchange we are trading on, denoted as
, has the top bid order at \$198 and the top ask order at \$202, so the mid price is \$200.

trading pair. That pair has a top bid order at \$200 while the top ask order is \$202, so the mid price is \$201. These discrepancies often happens between different exchanges as market conditions change. Some exchanges may react more slowly or quickly to market changes due to differences in the trading pair, liquidity, geography.
on Exchange B is more liquid and responds more quickly to market information than
on Exchange A, you may want to market make on Exchange A but use
on Exchange B as the price source. This helps you position your orders based on where the market might go in the future.
When using an external price source, an order may result in a crossed market. This means the order on the current exchange is placed with a price that matches an existing order in the book. Enabling
parameter allows the strategy to fill the matching maker order.

In certain cases, this behavior may be desirable even if the fee is higher because of the likely future price mitigation. This feature is only available when an external price source is used. When enabled, Hummingbot uses
Determines which market to be used as price reference when creating orders.

<Prompt
  prompt="Which price source to use? (current_market/external_market/custom_api)"
  response=">>> current_market"
/>
Price type to be used as price reference when creating orders.

<Prompt
  prompt="Which price type to use? (mid_price/last_price/last_own_trade_price/best_bid/best_ask/inventory_cost)"
  response=">>> mid_price"
/>

Hummingbot uses the mid price of the market's order book in the current exchange as reference e.g. if your bid/ask spread is set to 1, your orders will be created 1% away from the mid price. Mid price - is calculated (market best ask + market best bid) / 2.
Last price is the most recent price that the asset has been traded.
The bot uses the last own trade price as a price reference when creating orders.
, the price will be based on the best bid in the order book.
, the price will be based on the best ask in the order book.
The bot will calculate the average cost of your inventory every time a buy order is filled, and all sell orders will be created at

.
When using inventory_cost, you would need to set inventory price before you start your Hummingbot using this command
Name of exchange to be used for external pricing source.
<Prompt prompt="Enter external price source exchange name" response=">>> " />
The trading pair for the price source exchange.

<Prompt
  prompt="Enter the token pair on [price_source_exchange]"
  response=">>> "
/>
Take order if they cross orderbook when external price source is enabled.

<Prompt
  prompt="Do you want to take the best order if orders cross the orderbook? (Yes/No)"
  response=">>> Yes"
/>
An external API that returns price.
